text: thank you everybody for coming today my
name is Jeremy levy I'll be I'm the tech
lead at Google for the coop flow team
and I'll be presenting on behalf of J
Smith my colleague who couldn't be here
today so I'll be talking about how coop
flow is enabling CIC be pipelines for
machine learning and so today I'll be
talking about two different tools so one
of those is coop flow and the other is
going to be our go CD so briefly coop
flow is a kubernetes native platform for
machine learning so our mission is to
make it easy to for everyone to develop
deploy and manage portable distributed
ml on kubernetes and then the second one
is our go see B so our go CD is a tool
that enables get-ups for kubernetes
and it's basically a declarative
continuous delivery system for
kubernetes so this this slide basically
illustrates one of the core problems
that we're trying to solve with coop
flow so right now machine learning on
kubernetes is very difficult and the
reason that it's difficult is because if
you're trying to set up kubernetes to do
machine learning you end up having to
get to build the platform yourself by
cobbling together different services and
components so there's basically three
different component types of components
that you have to combine so the first
one is the ml specific components so
these could be applications like Jupiter
that enable data scientists there could
also be some of the applications we're
developing as part of coop flow so as
part of coop flow we have custom
controllers for doing things like
running distributed training on
kubernetes the next level of components
and services you have is would be
kubernetes specific components so these
might be networking components so a lot
of the applications you're deploying as
part of your machine learning platform
are web apps for example you have Tenzer
board which is a web application that
makes it easy to monitor the performance
of your models and see how they're doing
as you train them so if you want to
connect to this web app you need to set
up networking so you might need a
reverse proxy or you might need to set
up ingress you might also as the
previous talk mention need to set up and
install the GPU drivers so you can
properly configure your cluster to use
accelerators and then finally you have
the cluster infrastructure level bits
like actually setting up your cluster or
provisioning storage so we're solving
this with a two-step process so we
basically have a command-line tool
called KF cuddle and this is the way
this process works is we generate a
whole bunch of configurations in the
first step which we call the generate
phase and then the second phase we apply
those configs to your kubernetes cluster
to actually declare set up that
infrastructure and the reason that we
have this two-step process is because
this enables us to switch to a git ops
type workflow so with a git ops type
workflow what you do is after you
generate the configs instead of applying
them directly you push them to a git
repo and then you can use a tool like
argo CD or a tool like reflux which can
actually take those configs in your git
repo and then automatically synchronize
them to your your kubernetes cluster and
so the reason that we call that this
pattern is called get ops and the reason
it's called git OPS's because you can
basically operate your infrastructure
just by pull request because if you want
to make a change you just change the the
config file push it to your git repo and
then the tools will take care of
automatically syncing that change to
your infrastructure so this is what it
looks like with coop flow so these are
the commands with k-f cuddle to set up
your infrastructure so the first step
but like I said is you run the generate
command to generate your manifests you
then push them using the JIT command
line tool to your git repo the next step
would be to actually install our go CD
and all these commands are doing is
basically deploying the Argos CD Dameon
in your cluster and then we're
configuring the agro configuration to
set up an app and pointing that app at
our repo where we've defined our
kubernetes our coop flow cluster if you
then looked at the UI for our go the CD
you would see this icon indicating your
application and providing information
about your configuration like the git
repo that you're actually monitoring and
then after a while you would see it
actually sink all the manifests in your
cluster and now if you want to push a
change make a change to your cluster you
can just change the manifest so in this
case we've changed the configuration
from one of the operators
and if you look in the Argos UI you can
see this red box here that shows you
that your cluster is no longer in sync
and then you could use Argos CD to
automatically sync those changes to your
cluster so for more info you can look at
the coop flow Docs or an coop flow org
you can also look at the Argos CD Docs
to learn more about our go and I just
want to say thank you to the Argo team
at Intuit that helped us put this
together thank you very much
[Applause]
